properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong southerly winds will reach up to 90 km/h beginning this evening. The winds will ease late in the night. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-02T12:44:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-01T20:45:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1565700886.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall continues tonight into Wednesday. Snow will continue with additional snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 locally 15 cm possible tonight through Wednesday morning. Strong northerly winds gusting near 60 km/h are possible today, particularly near Lake Huron or Georgian Bay. This snowfall is a result of a strengthening low pressure system expected to move through eastern Ontario into Quebec today into Wednesday. Precipitation associated with this low pressure system is expected to move east of the area by Wednesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-02T13:19:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-01T21:20:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1766447637.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall continues tonight. Snow, heavy at times, and blowing snow will continue this evening into early Wednesday. Additional snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 centimetres are possible before the snow weakens tomorrow morning. Falling snow, along with wind gusts up to 70 km/h, will allow for blowing snow to occur and significantly affect visibilities tonight and early tomorrow morning. This snowfall is the result of a low pressure system that has moved into southern Quebec this evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warm, windy, and rainy conditions are expected for the southwest Yukon and northwestern B.C. tonight and Wednesday. Areas exposed to winds from the southeast could see gusts to 60 km/h tonight and Wednesday as a powerful storm remains over the Gulf of Alaska. These strong winds will maintain the gradual warm up through Wednesday. Snow will change to rain later this evening as temperatures rise above freezing. Periods of rain are expected to continue through Wednesday with the potential for some areas to see 10 to 30 mm through Wednesday afternoon. These temperatures are 10 to 20 degrees Celsius above seasonal normals for this time of year. More seasonal conditions will return on Thursday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-02T16:18:24-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, continues. Additional rainfall amounts: 30 to 50 mm, locally 70 mm in heaviest rain bands. Locations: western Nova Scotia and the north shore of the Minas Basin. Time span: tonight through Wednesday morning. Remarks: Heavy rain will continue tonight. Over southwestern Nova Scotia, 25 to 40 mm has already fallen. The highest rainfall amounts are expected in the southwest where amounts could reach upwards of 70 mm by Wednesday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and local blowing snow continues this evening. An additional 5 to 10 cm of snow is possible, mainly between Sarnia and London. Hazards: 5 to 10 cm of additional snow Blowing snow Wind gusts to 70 km/h Impacts: Poor visibility in quickly accumulating snow and blowing snow Poor road conditions Worst impacts expected between Watford and London Timing: Continuing now through early Wednesday morning 20-30 cm of snow has been reported at London Airport and by weather spotters in Parkhill and Strathroy so far through this event. Widespread snow will continue across the area, but the bulk of the heavy snow should be focused between Watford and London this evening before gradually easing overnight. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Multi-day snowfall event continues this evening into overnight. Additional snowfall amounts of 2 to 5 locally 10 cm are possible tonight through Wednesday morning. Motorists should be prepared for winter driving conditions. This snowfall is a result of a strengthening low pressure system expected to move through eastern Ontario into Quebec today into Wednesday. Precipitation associated with this low pressure system is expected to move east of the area overnight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
